Hello {first_name, "there"},

We're still very much riding the first wave of analysis from the Digital News Report that launched yesterday - but there's at least one good read and one good listen below that isn't based on that.

Thanks to everyone who got in contact with responses to yesterday's piece of analysis - you've given me plenty to think about, research — and write.

Adam

— Adam Becket (@adambecket) June 17, 2020

sections: Journalists on social media: a reappraisal
It's clear we're about to go through a reassessment of how journalists should behave on social media — and Twitter in particular. This came up in passing during the discussion about the
yesterday, and is in the news again today:
I've had a couple of interesting discussions about the
over the past 24 hours, and one of the (many) causes several people pinpointed was the blurring of news and opinion both in publications, but especially on social media.

This doesn't have to be the case. There are several journalists I admire — and, in some cases, know personally — whose politics are a mystery to me. They maintain an active and useful social media presence without joining in the open political warfare that exists on Twitter.
And then there are people like

who are far more polemicists than journalists in the traditional sense. The solution lies far more with the "political blank states" than it does with the political outriders, and it's important we have this conversation right now.
The damage this is doing to the reputation of journalism as a profession needs addressing. And it's making social media an ever-more toxic environment for all journalists.

Big, big fan of this approach to sweating the archives.
Instagram to eclipse Twitter as a news source

Probably only a surprise to journalists, who have an obsession with Twitter out of all proportion to its actual userbase, but this key finding from the Digital News Report ought to be informing more audience engagement strategies than it is.
Shame it means a greater consolidation of power in the hands of Facebook, though…
The changing face of news podcasts
Esther digs deep into the podcast section of the Digital News Report, and finds things like this:

With half of all respondents saying that podcasts provide more depth and understanding than other types of media, the opportunities for publishers looking to engage their audiences on a deeper level have never been clearer.
It's only taken 15 years, but podcasts are slowly becoming a critical part of the journalistic offering…
